metadata.name: Language and Style Dataset
metadata.description: Language patterns and stylistic elements from Grimms' Fairy Tales

vocabulary_choices.text: Use concrete nouns over abstract concepts (forest, castle, gold vs. anxiety, philosophy)
Choose simple, direct verbs (went, said, saw vs. proceeded, articulated, observed)
Employ functional adjectives (beautiful, poor, old, golden, little, great, wicked)
Include occasional archaic terms (prithee, nay, alas, whither, hark ye, dwelt)
Avoid scientific, technical, or modern vocabulary entirely

sentence_patterns.text: Use simple Subject-Verb-Object structure for most sentences
Connect clauses with 'and,' 'but,' 'so,' 'then' rather than complex conjunctions
Begin many sentences with 'Then' or 'So' to create rhythmic progression
Limit sentence length, avoiding multiple subordinate clauses
Use active voice almost exclusively, with passive voice only for emphasis

narrative_voice.text: Maintain a matter-of-fact, declarative tone throughout
Report magical or gruesome events without emotional commentary
Avoid irony, sarcasm, or modern self-awareness
Use omniscient narration but rarely interpret characters' thoughts
Present moral judgments through consequences, not narrator commentary

dialogue_patterns.text: Keep dialogue brief and functional rather than conversational
Use direct speech markers ('he said', 'she replied') without variation
Include formal or ritualistic speech patterns for magical beings
Differentiate social classes through speech patterns (royalty vs. peasants)
Employ repeated dialogue phrases for emphasis or magical effect

poetic_devices.text: Insert rhyming couplets for spells, magical messages, or significant moments
Use simple AABB or ABCB rhyme schemes for magical verses
Create repetitive phrases that recur throughout the narrative
Employ rule of three in descriptions, actions, and plot elements
Develop incantatory rhythm through parallel sentence structures

description_techniques.text: Focus on action and function rather than appearance in descriptions
Describe characters through simple, defining traits (youngest son, beautiful princess)
Use minimal setting details, focusing on story-relevant elements
Avoid extended metaphors or complex imagery
Describe emotional states through external actions rather than internal feelings

time_and_transitions.text: Use vague time markers ('once upon a time', 'after some time passed')
Employ direct transitions between scenes without elaborate bridges
Signal the passage of time through simple phrases ('the next day', 'for many years')
Create episodic structure with clear beginnings and endings to scenes
Use formulaic opening and closing phrases to frame the narrative
